Situation1: Their parents directly open up about a personal struggle and look to them for comfort.
Expectation2: Recite and reflect on the Quran
Situation2: Ramadan’s midpoint arrives and the daily reading quota is slightly behind.
Story: I sat on the living room floor, the Quran open in my lap, my finger tracing the lines I needed to catch up on. Ramadan was halfway through, and I was already behind on my daily reading. I could hear the clock ticking, each second reminding me of the promise I made to myself to finish the Quran this month. Just as I was about to start reciting, my mother sat down beside me, her eyes red and tired. She began to talk, her voice trembling as she shared her worries about Dad’s job and the bills piling up. I could feel her need for comfort, for me to listen and reassure her. But my mind kept drifting to the pages in front of me, the verses I hadn’t read, the spiritual commitment I was falling short on. I wanted to be the child she needed, to hold her hand and tell her everything would be okay. At the same time, I felt the weight of my faith, the expectation to honor this sacred month and not let my reading slip further behind. My heart pulled in two directions, I sat there, torn, unsure which role to answer first.
